Graphical abstract This work aims the preparation and catalytic use of copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria as catalyst in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. They were in situ generated from the reduction of Cu2+/CeO2 during the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene. The results of characterization by using XRD, SEM, SEM-EDX, TEM, UV–vis, XPS techniques reveal the formation of highly dispersed copper(0) nanoparticles with average particle size of 3.1±0.8nm on the surface of ceria nanopowders. Cu(0)/CeO2 nanoparticles are active catalysts releasing 1.0equiv. H2 per mole of dimethylamine borane. The catalytic activity of Cu(0)/CeO2 shows variation with the copper loading of ceria and the highest catalytic activity is achieved by using Cu(0)/CeO2 sample with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% Cu which provides a turnover frequency value of 40h−1 and 225 turnovers in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C. The equation for the catalytic reaction was established by determining all the products. We performed the kinetic studies for understanding the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in molecular level. The results of kinetic study reveal that the reaction is first order with respect to catalyst concentration. The work reported here also includes the kinetic study depending on the temperature to determine the activation energy (E a =76±2kJ/mol). Keywords Cerium(IV) oxide Copper nanoparticles Hydrogen generation Dimethylamine borane Heterogeneous catalyst 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) is one of the sustainable and environmentally benign energy carriers [1,2]. The controlled and efficient storage of hydrogen is the key issue in the Hydrogen Economy [3,4]. Amine boranes have been considered as solid hydrogen storage materials because of their stability and high H2 storage capacity [5–7]. Of particular interest is the dimethylamine borane ((CH3)2NHBH3, DMAB) which can release hydrogen in the presence of suitable catalyst under mild conditions (Eq. (1)) [8–10]. (1) 2 Me 2 NH ⋅ BH 3 ⟶ catalyst ( Me 2 N ⋅ BH 2 ) 2 + 2 H 2 So far various homogeneous and heterogeneous transition metal catalysts have been tested for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. Although the highest catalytic activity has been achieved by using the homogeneous catalyst [η5-C5H3-1,3-(SiMe3)2Ti]2 [11] in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane (Table 1 ) current research has been shifted to the development of heterogeneous catalysts due to the simple product separation and catalyst recovery [12]. Transition metal nanoparticles are highly active catalysts in many reactions. Among the various transition metals, copper nanoparticles have received considerable attention because copper is one of the earth abundant materials which finds versatile applications in different fields of research [13]. Copper nanoparticles have been broadly used as alternative catalysts, in many industrially important reactions such as hydrogenation and methanol synthesis [14,15] due to the much lower cost of copper compared to the precious noble metals. However, transition metal nanoparticles have tendency to agglomerate to larger particles and ultimately to the bulk metal which causes a significant loss in catalytic activity [16,17]. Supporting on the surface of suitable materials is an efficient way of preventing the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles [18]. Recently, ceria appears to be one of the suitable supporting materials for noble metal nanoparticles due to its high chemical stability [19]. Ceria can improve the performance of late transition metals through strong metal–support interaction [20,21]. We have recently shown that using ceria nanopowders as support provides high catalytic activity and long lifetime for Pd [22], Ru [23] and Rh [24] nanoparticles in hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of ammonia borane. This result prompted us to employ ceria as support for a non-noble metal nanoparticles catalyst in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. Herein we report the in situ generation, characterization, and catalytic activity of copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria nanopowders. Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles (Cu(0)/CeO2) are low-cost catalysts in comparison with the noble metals in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. Cu(0)/CeO2 has a remarkable catalytic activity with a turnover frequency of 40h−1 in releasing 1equiv. of pure H2 gas per mole of (CH3)2NHBH3 at 60.0±0.5°C. The results of the reusability tests and catalytic life time experiments indicate that Cu(0)/CeO2 is an efficient catalyst in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (Cu[CH3(CH2)3CH(C2H5)CO2]2), dimethylamine borane ((CH3)2NHBH3, DMAB, 97%) and ceria (CeO2, 25nm, BET surface area 48.1m2 g−1) were purchased from Aldrich. Deionized water was distilled by water purification system (Milli Q-pure WS). Toluene was distilled over sodium metal and stored under inert gas atmosphere before using in all dehydrogenation reactions unless otherwise specified. All glassware and Teflon coated magnetic stir bars were cleaned with acetone, followed by copious rinsing with distilled water before drying in an oven at 150°C. 2.2 Formation of copper(0) nanoparticles and concomitant catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane All reactions were performed under a dry nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques including a vacuum system unless otherwise specified. The experimental set up is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The jacketed reaction flask was kept under vacuum at least for 30min and filled with dry nitrogen gas to remove any trace of oxygen before all catalytic reactions. The reaction flask was thermostated by circulating water through its jacket at 60°C. The gas outlet of the reaction flask was connected to a graduated glass tube with water through a bubbler containing 10mL of methylcyclohexane (Fig. 1). Copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria were in situ generated during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. A stock solution of copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (Stock A) was prepared by dissolving 76.6mg (0.218mmol) copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate in 25mL toluene. In a typical experiment, under nitrogen purging, a 7.50mL aliquot of the Stock A solution (8.74mM Cu) was added to the reaction flask containing 100mg ceria trough a septum by using a 10mL syringe, which had been nitrogen-flushed three times. The reaction flask was thermostated by circulating water through its jacket at 60.0±0.5°C or at a specified temperature. When a thermal equilibrium was reached, a solution of 60.1mg (1.0mmol) DMAB in 2.5mL toluene was added via a gastight syringe to the reaction flask containing the suspension of Cu2+/nanoceria in toluene and the reaction was started by stirring the mixture at 1000rpm. Reduction of copper(II) to copper(0) and the release of hydrogen gas from the dehydrogenation of DMAB was seen concomitantly after the addition of DMAB into the reaction mixture within in a short induction period. The volume of hydrogen gas evolved during the catalytic reaction was followed by measuring the displacement of water level in the glass tube at constant pressure, which was then converted into the equivalent H2 per mole DMAB. The reaction was stopped when no more hydrogen evolution was observed. 2.3 Determination of the most active copper loading for Cu(0)/CeO2 in the dehydrogenation of DMAB To find the most active copper loading for Cu(0)/CeO2 various copper loadings in the range of 1.0–6.0wt.% were tested in hydrogen generation from dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with 6.56mM Cu and 100mM DMAB in 10mL toluene solution at 60.0±0.5°C. The highest activity was achieved by using 4.0wt.% copper loaded on 100mg ceria. For all the other catalytic reactions, Cu(0)/CeO2 with the loading of 4.0wt.% Cu was used unless otherwise stated. 2.4 Preparation of Cu2+-ion impregnated on nanoceria surface The stock solution (Stok A) prepared in Section 2.2 was also used for the Preparation of Cu2+- ion impregnated on nanoceria. For each catalytic experiment an aliquot of the Stock A solution was transferred into the reaction flask containing 100mg nanoceria for obtaining samples with various loading of copper in the range of 1–6wt.% The resulting suspension was then stirred for 75min to ensure a complete adherence of Cu2+ ions to the nanoceria support at 25.0±0.5°C. 2.5 Determination of activation parameters for dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane catalyzed by Cu(0)/CeO2 In order to get activation parameters, catalytic dehydrogenation reaction of 100mM DMAB was performed starting with 6.56mM Cu (4.0wt.%) at various temperatures (60, 55, 50, 45°C). The values of the rate constant were determined from the plots of hydrogen versus time and used to calculate the activation energy, enthalpy change of activation, and entropy change of activation by drawing Eyring–Polanyi plot. 2.6 Leaching test and kinetic competence of Cu(0)/CeO2 in the hydrogen generation of dimethylamine borane After the first run of catalytic dehydrogenation of substrate starting with 10mL of 100mM DMAB (60.12mg (CH3)2NH.BH3) and 6.56mM Cu(II) impregnated on 100mg ceria (4.0wt.% Cu) at 60.0±0.5°C, the catalyst was allowed to settle down, the reaction solution was then filtered into another reaction flask under inert gas atmosphere. The isolated solid and the filtrate solution were tested for their catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane under the same reaction conditions by adding a new batch of DMAB (100mM). In addition, filtrate solution was analyzed by ICP-OES to confirm that no copper leached into the solution from the surface of nanoceria during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. 2.7 Recyclability of ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles in the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane After the complete dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in the first run, a second batch of DMAB (60.12mg) was added to the solution without removing anything from the reaction medium. The catalytic activity was measured by monitoring the rate of hydrogen generation. 2.8 Determination of catalytic lifetime of Cu(0)/CeO2 in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane The catalytic lifetime of Cu(0)/CeO2 in the dehydrogenation of DMAB was determined by measuring the total turnover number (TTO). Such a lifetime experiment was started with a 10mL toluene solution containing 6.56mM Cu(0)/CeO2 and 250mM DMAB. When the complete conversion was achieved, more DMAB was added into the reaction flask under N2 purging. 2.9 Carbon disulfide poisoning test for Cu(0)/CeO2 in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane A stock solution of CS2 in toluene (Stock B) was prepared by dissolving 120μL CS2 in total 25mL toluene under inert atmosphere and used for performing the catalyst poisoning experiments,. A typical catalytic dehydrogenation reaction was started with 6.56mM Cu (4.0wt.% Cu, Cu(0)/CeO2) at 60.0±0.5 ∘C. After 40% conversion of reaction was attained, 0.2equiv. (1.31mM, μL 160) CS2 per copper was added to the reaction medium via a gastight syringe in order to poison the catalyst. The hydrogen generation ceased immediately upon the addition of CS2 solution and reaction was followed for 30min to observe no further hydrogen evolution. 2.10 Characterization Solid samples used for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray Diffraction Pattern (XRD) or Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) analysis were harvested from Cu(0)/CeO2 solution at the end of dehydrogenation reactions by removing volatiles in vacuum. The XPS analysis was performed on a Physical Electronics 5800 spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical analyzer and using monochromatic Al-Ka radiation (1486.6eV, the X-ray tube working at 15kV, 350W and pass energy of 23.5keV). The C 1s peak at 284.5eV was used as reference for surface charging. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed with Field Emission Gun (FEG) on a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 microscope operating at 300kV. The TEM samples were harvested from in situ generated Cu(0)/nanoceria solution at the end of catalytic reaction of DMAB. A 1mL aliquot of nanoparticle solution was diluted in 5mL ethanol and ultrasonicated for 3min. The colloidal solution was deposited on carbon coated copper grid by immersing the grid into the solution for 5s and then dried under inert atmosphere. The particle size of nanoparticles was calculated directly from the TEM image by counting non-touching particles. A scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL 6390-LV) with the accelerating voltage of 20kV was used to investigate the surface morphology of the sample. The XRD pattern was recorded on a Rigaku Multiflex 2kW diffractometer with Cu-Ka radiation (λ =1.5418Å) in the range 2θ =10–90° at a scan of 5°/min and a step increment of 0.02° at room temperature. UV–vis. electronic absorption spectra of precursor copper salt and copper(0) nanoparticles were generated at room temperature in a 1cm quartz cuvette using a Shimadzu-2450 double beam spectrometer with a 100μL solution and a spectral range of 200–800nm. The copper contents of the samples were determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Leeman-Direct Reading Echelle) after each sample was completely dissolved in nitric acid. 11B NMR analyses were recorded in d8-Toluene on Bruker Avance DPX 400MHz spectrometer (128.15MHz for 11B NMR). BF3(C2H5)2O were used as the external reference for 11B NMR chemical shifts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation of copper(0) nanoparticles Copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate was used as a precursor for the formation of copper(0) nanoparticles catalyst in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution. In situ formation of copper(0) nanoparticles from the reduction of copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate and concomitant H2 release from the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane occur in the same medium. When copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate is added to the toluene solution of dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C, a fast hydrogen evolution starts immediately without induction period (Fig. 2 ). However, the hydrogen evolution slows down after the release of about 0.5equiv. H2 per mole of DMAB (ca 10min) indicating deactivation of the catalyst formed. During the reduction of the precursor Cu(C7H15CO2)2, the reaction solution gradually changes its color from greenish-blue to red within less than 10min indicating the formation of copper(0) nanoparticles. This color change implies that the reaction can be followed by monitoring the changes in the UV–vis electronic absorption spectrum of solution. The starting solution containing 30mM copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate in toluene exhibits an intense absorption band at λ max =296nm and a broad band at λ max =668nm in the spectrum (Fig. 3 ). Comparing to the literature values [25], the broad band at 668nm is attributed to the d–d transition and the strong band at 296nm to the LMCT transition in Cu(C7H15CO2)2. The spectral features change immediately when DMAB is added to the solution and a new band grows in at 361nm, which can be assigned to copper(0) nanoparticles [26] in addition to the plasmon resonance band [27]. The latter two bands lose intensity as the reaction proceeds and ultimately disappear within 1h. Concomitantly, the reaction solution becomes clear with the precipitation of bulk metal. This observation indicates that copper(0) nanoparticles, formed from the reduction of copper(II) ions during dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane, are not stable and therefore converted to the bulk metal within a short time. The only potential stabilizer present in the reaction solution is 2-ethylhexanoate ion which does not provide enough stabilization for the copper(0) nanoparticles against agglomeration [16]. The decreasing in the catalytic activity is another evidence for the agglomeration of copper(0) nanoparticles (Fig. 2). In order to stabilize the in situ generated copper(0) nanoparticles against agglomeration they were supported on the surface of ceria nanopowders. Copper(0) nanoparticles supported on nanoceria (Cu(0)/CeO2) were in situ generated from the reduction of copper(II) ions impregnated on nanoceria (Cu2+/CeO2) during the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. When dimethylamine borane was added to a suspension of Cu2+/CeO2 in toluene, both the formation of copper(0) nanoparticles and catalytic dehydrogenation of DMAB occur concomitantly. The progress of copper(0) nanoparticles formation and concomitant dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane was followed by monitoring the volume of H2 generated, which was then converted into the equivalent H2 per mole of DMAB, using the known 1:1 H2/DMAB stoichiometry (Eq. (1)). Fig. 4 shows the plot of equivalent H2 per mole of DMAB versus time for the dehydrogenation of DMAB starting with Cu2+/CeO2 precatalyst (6.56mM Cu) and 100mM DMAB in 10mL toluene at 60±0.5°C. The formation kinetics of the copper(0) nanoparticles can be obtained using the dehydrogenation of DMAB as reporter reaction [28,29] (Scheme 1 ), in which A is the added precursor Cu(C7H15CO2)2 and B is the growing copper(0) nanoparticles. The observation of a sigmodial dehydrogenation curve and its curve fit to the slow, continuous nucleation A→B (rate constant k 1) followed by autocatalytic surface growth A+B→2B (rate constant k 2) kinetics is very strong evidence for the formation of a metal(0) nanoparticle catalyst from a transition-metal complex in the presence of a reducing agent [28]. The rate constants determined from the nonlinear least-squares curve fit in Fig. 4 are k 1 =1.10×10−2 ±1.63×10−3 min−1 and k 2 =2.80±1.31×10−2 M−1 min−1 (the mathematically required correction has been made to k 2 for the stoichiometry factor of 16, as described elsewhere [29]), but not for the ‘scaling factor’; that is, no correction has been made for the number of Cu atoms on the growing metal surface. 3.2 Characterization of copper (0) nanoparticles supported on CeO2 The ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles, in situ formed from the reduction of copper(II) precursor during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane, were isolated from the reaction solution and characterized by XRD, SEM-EDS, TEM and XPS techniques. The XRD patterns of CeO2 and Cu(0)/CeO2 with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% Cu, given in Fig. 5a and b, respectively, exhibits the characteristic diffraction peaks of CeO2 at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.5°, 76.8°, and 79.1° assigned to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) reflections of CeO2 (ICDD Card 34-0394). The comparison of XRD patterns of two samples clearly show that there is no observable peak which would be attributed to copper, most likely due to low copper loading on ceria. Furthermore, no change is observed in the positions of ceria diffraction peaks. Hence, one can conclude that copper loading does not alter the structure of support. However, crystallite size of pure ceria and Cu(0)/CeO2 sample were calculated by using the Debye–Scherrer equation as 24.9nm and 13.4nm, respectively. Thus, one can conclude that copper loading during the catalytic process causes a decrement of the crystallite size and relative intensity of the main peak of CeO2 in Fig. 4. The presence of copper nanoparticles in the loaded sample may cause a decrease in the crystallinity of host material. “SEM was used to study the morphology of the surface of ceria and Cu(0)/CeO2. Fig. 6 displays the SEM image of pure ceria and ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles with a metal loading of 4.0wt.% SEM-EDX spectrum and elemental mapping of Cu(0)/CeO2 with a metal loading of 4.0wt.% given in Fig. 6 indicate that copper is the only element detected in addition to the framework elements of ceria (Ce, O). Moreover, SEM-EDX results show that the copper loading is 4.0wt.% for Cu (0)/CeO2 sample as seen from the table in the inset of Fig. 6d. This indicates that all the copper are on the surface of ceria. Additionally, the mapped SEM micrograph analyses of the sample indicate good elemental distribution in the copper loaded ceria sample.” Fig. 7 depicts the TEM images of Cu(0)/CeO2 with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% taken at different magnifications after catalytic reaction indicating a uniform dispersion of copper(0) nanoparticles on the surface of ceria nanopowders. Fig. 7d shows the particle size histogram of copper(0) nanoparticles constructed by measuring the size of more than 100 non-touching particles from different TEM images. The histogram (Fig. 7d) indicates the presence of highly dispersed copper(0) nanoparticles on the ceria surface in the range 1.8–5.3nm with an average particle size 3.1±0.8nm. Selected area diffraction pattern (SAED) of ceria supported copper nanoparticles given in the inset of Fig. 7a shows the diffraction pattern of the area indicated in the corresponding TEM image. The observation of ring pattern with three (111), (200) and (220) diffractions indicates the existence of face centered cubic copper [30]. The BET surface area was determined to be 48.1 and 48.7m2 g−1 for CeO2 and Cu(0)/CeO2 with a copper loading of 4.0wt.%, respectively. No apparent change in surface area was observed after copper loading of ceria support. The composition of Cu(0)/CeO2 formed in situ during the dehydrogenation of DMAB and the oxidation state of copper were also studied by XPS technique (Fig. 8 ). The survey-scan XPS spectrum of Cu(0)/CeO2 with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% (Fig. 8) shows that copper is the only element detected in addition to the ceria framework elements (Ce, O) in agreement with SEM-EDX result. Fig. 8 shows the high resolution scan and deconvolution for the Cu 2p core of Cu(0)/CeO2 indicating two prominent peaks at 930.6 and 950.8eV which are assigned to copper(0) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [31]. Two relatively weak peaks observed at 933.8 and 952.2eV are attributable to copper(II) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [32,33]. Additional weak peaks are due to shake up process. CuO is most likely formed upon air exposure of Cu(0)/CeO2 during the XPS sampling [34]. The high resolution XPS spectra of Ce 3d core for the CeO2 and Cu(0)/CeO2 with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% samples are depicted in Fig. 8c. The two spectra in Fig. 8c are essentially the same as given in the literature [35]. No noticeable change in the spectrum of Ce 3d is observable upon copper loading. 3.3 Catalytic activity of Cu(0)/CeO2 in dehydrogenation of DMAB In a control experiment starting with 1.0mmol DMAB and 100mg powder of CeO2 (the same amount as the one used in catalytic activity experiments) in 10mL of toluene solution at 60.0±0.5°C, no hydrogen evolution was observed over 2h indicating that nanoceria support is catalytically silent in the dehydrogenation of DMAB. The same experiment was performed starting with Cu(0)/CeO2 samples having different loading of copper in the range 1–6wt.% Cu and the same amount of ceria support (100mg CeO2) in 10mL toluene at 60.0±0.5°C. The copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria nanopowders were found to be highly active catalyst in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. Note that all the experiments for measuring the catalytic activity of Cu(0)/CeO2 samples were performed at least three times to estimate the percent error in the results of each experiment. Fig. 9a shows the plots of mol H2 evolved per mole of DMAB versus time for the experiments performed starting with Cu(0)/CeO2 samples of different copper loading in the range 2–6wt.% in the dehydrogenation of 100mM DMAB to determine the effect of copper loading on the catalytic activity of ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. The turnover frequency (TOF) values in the catalytic dehydrogenation reactions of dimethylamine borane were calculated from the slope of each plot in linear portion and found to be 33, 35, 40, and 25h−1 for Cu(0)/CeO2 samples containing 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 6.0wt.% Cu, respectively. Plotting the TOF versus copper loading gives a volcano shape variation for the catalytic activity of copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria nanopowders in the dehydrogenation of DMAB at 60.0±0.5°C (Fig. 9b). The highest catalytic activity (TOF=40h−1) was achieved by using the 4.0wt.% copper loaded ceria sample. As the copper loading further increases, the catalytic activity of Cu(0)/CeO2 decreases, most probably due to the agglomeration of nanoparticles, resulting in a decrease in the surface area and the accessibility of active sites. Therefore, Cu(0)/CeO2 samples with copper loading of 4.0wt.% were used in all the further experiments in this study. The apparent TOF value of 40h−1 is comparable with that of the prior best heterogeneous catalyst (ruthenium nanoparticles, TOF=137h−1) [45], but much higher than those of the other heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, with one exception of homogeneous titanocene catalyst [11], reported for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane up to now (Table 1). In order to study the effect of catalyst concentration on the catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of DMAB, a series of experiments were performed starting with various amounts of ceria while keeping the copper loading constant at 4.0wt.% Fig. 10 shows the plots of mol H2 per mole of dimethylamine borane versus time during the catalytic dehydrogenation of 100mM DMAB solution in the presence of Cu(0)/CeO2 nanoparticles in different copper concentrations (1.64, 3.27, 4.92 and 6.56mM) at 60.0±0.5°C. The hydrogen generation rate was determined from the linear portion of each plot. The plot of hydrogen generation rate versus copper concentration, both in logarithmic scale (the inset in Fig. 10), gives a straight line with a slope of 1.16 indicating that the dehydrogenation reaction is first order with respect to the catalyst concentration. The catalytic dehydrogenation of DMAB was also carried out at different temperatures in the range of (45–60°C) starting with Cu2+/CeO2, copper loading 4.0wt.% Cu, copper concentration [Cu]=6.56mM and substrate concentration [DMAB]=100mM. Expectedly, the rate of hydrogen generation from dehydrogenation of DMAB increases with increasing temperature. The rate constants for the dehydrogenation of DMAB at different temperatures were calculated from the slope in linear part of each plot given in Fig. 11a and used for the construction of Arrhenius [48] and Eyring [49] plots given in Fig. 11b and 11c, respectively, yielding the activation energy E a =76±2kJ/mol, activation enthalpy ΔH # =80±2kJ/mol. After the completion of dehydrogenation performed starting with 6.56mM Cu/CeO2 plus 100mM DMAB in 10mL toluene at 60.0±0.5°C, the suspension was filtered and both the isolated solid and the filtrate solution were tested for their catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane under the same reaction conditions by adding a new batch of DMAB (100mM). As shown in Fig. 12 , the filtrate solution is silent in the dehydrogenation of DMAB indicating that there is no leaching of copper into the solution during the dehydrogenation reaction. The filtrate solution was also analyzed by ICP-OES for its copper content and found to have 0.005mM copper. Compared to the initial concentration of 6.56mM Cu, this small value indicates that the copper leaching into the solution is negligible. On the other hand, the isolated solid materials show catalytic activity when dispersed in 10mL DMAB solution (100mM). Compared to the initial catalytic activity (TOF=40h−1) one observes a decrease in catalytic activity (TOF=20h−1) of the solid materials. This decrease in catalytic activity may be due to the loss of materials during the isolation and/or agglomeration of copper(0) nanoparticles to the large particles. Nevertheless, these two observations indicate that copper(0) nanoparticles supported on CeO2 are kinetically competent catalyst in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. The mechanism of catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane over the transition metal center has been well established by identifying the intermediates [50]. Dimethylamine borane binds to the copper center through BH3 group forming an inner sphere intermediate which undergoes first H-transfer and then β-hydrogen elimination from N-H bond yielding the metastable Me2N=BH2. The latter intermediate is not stable and converted to the stable cyclic dimer. In a complementary experiment, the 11B-NMR spectrum, taken from the reaction solution at the end of the dehydrogenation of DMAB, shows that Me2NHBH3 (δ =−14ppm, q) is completely converted to the cyclic dimer [Me2NBH2]2 (δ =5ppm, t). In a control experiment, after the completion of hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of DMAB starting with 6.56mM Cu(0)/CeO2 plus 100mM DMAB in 10mL toluene solution at 60.0±0.5°C, a second batch of DMAB was added to the solution without removing anything from the reaction flask and the hydrogen release from the DMAB was monitored as before. The complete release of hydrogen is achieved in both of the catalytic reactions of DMAB catalyzed by ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles. A noticeable decrease in catalytic activity was observed in the second run of dehydrogenation of DMAB added directly into the solution. However, the complete release of 1equiv. H2 is achieved in the second run as well (Fig. 13a). The decrease in catalytic activity in the second run of dehydrogenation is due to agglomeration of copper(0) nanoparticles. Indeed, one observes an increase in average particle size of copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria as seen from the TEM image (Fig. 13b) and corresponding histogram (Fig. 13c) of the sample harvested after the second run of dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. Catalytic lifetime of Cu(0)/CeO2 catalyst was determine by measuring the total turnover number (TTO) in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. A lifetime experiment was performed starting with 6.56mM Cu (copper loading on ceria is 4.0wt.% Cu) in 10mL solution of DMAB at 60.0±0.5°C. Fig. 14 shows the variations in total turnover number (TTO) and turnover frequency (TOF) versus time during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane by Cu(0)/CeO2 at 60.0±0.5°C. Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles provide 225 total turnovers in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C before deactivation. The observation of a decrease in the TOF value during the reaction indicates that the deactivation of the catalyst is due to the aggregation of metal nanoparticles. The heterogeneity of Cu(0)/CeO2 catalyst was tested by poisoning experiment. Due to the strong binding of poison to the metal center, the access of the substrate to the active site is blocked by poison [51,52]. In our poisoning experiment, carbon disulfide was used as poison and 0.2equiv. CS2 per mole of catalyst was injected into the reaction solution during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. In a typical poisoning experiment, after the liberation of 40% hydrogen from dehydrogenation of DMAB (100mM) catalyzed by 6.56mM Cu (4.0wt.% Cu) in 10mL toluene solution, 0.2equiv. CS2 per mole of catalyst was added to the reaction medium at 60.0±0.5°C. Fig. 15 exhibits the plot of mole H2 evolved per mole of DMAB versus time for the catalytic dehydrogenation of DMAB before and after addition of CS2 poison. It is clearly seen that the reaction is entirely ceased upon addition of 0.2equiv.s of CS2 per mole of Cu catalyst in a very short time which indicates that the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane catalyzed by ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles is indeed heterogeneous catalysis. 4 Conclusion The main findings and conclusions of this work can be summarized as follows: a) Copper(0) nanoparticles are formed from the reduction of copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane at 60±0.5°C and initially active catalysts in hydrogen generation. However, they are not stable and undergo aggregation to the bulk metal. b) Stable copper(0) nanoparticles can be obtained when the reduction of copper(II) to copper(0) is performed on the surface of ceria nanopowders. The resulting nanoparticles are active catalyst providing a release of 1.0equiv. of H2 per mole of dimethylamine borane. c) The results of characterization reveal the formation of highly dispersed copper(0) nanoparticles with an average particle size of 3.1±0.8nm on the ceria surface. d) Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles with a loading of 4.0wt.% Cu provide the highest activity with turnover frequency of 40h−1 in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C. e) Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles can provide only 225 turnovers in generation of H2 from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C before they are deactivated. Thus, the catalytic lifetime of Cu(0)/CeO2 nanoparticles (225 TTO) is significantly lower than the ones reported for the precious metal catalysts. Nevertheless, Cu(0)/CeO2 nanoparticles can be considered as cost-effective catalyst compared to the precious metals such as Ru and Rh based catalyst system in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. f) Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles are shown to be heterogeneous and kinetically competent catalysts in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. g) Low cost, easy preparation, relatively high stability, and high catalytic activity of nanoceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles make them promising candidate to be exploited as catalyst in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane. coredata.dc:description: This work aims the preparation and catalytic use of copper(0) nanoparticles supported on ceria as catalyst in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. They were in situ generated from the reduction of Cu2+/CeO2 during the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene. The results of characterization by using XRD, SEM, SEM-EDX, TEM, UV–vis, XPS techniques reveal the formation of highly dispersed copper(0) nanoparticles with average particle size of 3.1±0.8nm on the surface of ceria nanopowders. Cu(0)/CeO2 nanoparticles are active catalysts releasing 1.0equiv. H2 per mole of dimethylamine borane. The catalytic activity of Cu(0)/CeO2 shows variation with the copper loading of ceria and the highest catalytic activity is achieved by using Cu(0)/CeO2 sample with a copper loading of 4.0wt.% Cu which provides a turnover frequency value of 40h−1 and 225 turnovers in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.5°C. The equation for the catalytic reaction was established by determining all the products. We performed the kinetic studies for understanding the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in molecular level. The results of kinetic study reveal that the reaction is first order with respect to catalyst concentration. The work reported here also includes the kinetic study depending on the temperature to determine the activation energy (E a =76±2kJ/mol).
coredata.dc:title: Ceria supported copper(0) nanoparticles as efficient and cost-effective catalyst for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane
